video.title: Learn React JS - Full Course for Beginners - Tutorial 2019
video.description:
React.js is a JavaScript library for building dynamic web applications. Upon completion of this course, you'll know everything you need in order to build web applications in React. You can also try the interactive version of the course here: https://scrimba.com/g/glearnreact

This comprehensive introduction to React was created by Bob Ziroll (@bobziroll). Bob is the Director of Education at V School, an award-winning school of technology education.

🔗Tutorial Hell link mentioned in video: https://codeburst.io/digging-my-way-out-of-tutorial-hell-6dd5f9927384
🔗Virtual DOM video mentioned: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BYbgopx44vo

Check top comment to see what code you have to add to get React working locally.

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Course Introduction & Philosophy
⌨️ (0:05:22) What we'll be building
⌨️ (0:06:24) Why React?
⌨️ (0:09:25) ReactDOM & JSX
⌨️ (0:16:19) ReactDOM & JSX Practice
⌨️ (0:20:34) Functional Components
⌨️ (0:24:32) Functional Components Practice
⌨️ (0:29:41) Move Components into Separate Files
⌨️ (0:35:07) Parent/Child Components
⌨️ (0:43:14) Parent/Child Component Practice
⌨️ (0:48:12) Todo App - Phase 1
⌨️ (0:50:50) Styling React with CSS Classes
⌨️ (0:55:56) Some Caveats
⌨️ (0:58:12) JSX to JavaScript and Back
⌨️ (1:02:11) Inline Styles with the Style Property
⌨️ (1:09:21) Todo App - Phase 2
⌨️ (1:12:42) Props Part 1 - Understanding the Concept
⌨️ (1:14:56) Props Part 2 - Reusable Components
⌨️ (1:17:29) Props in React
⌨️ (1:29:39) Props and Styling Practice
⌨️ (1:40:25) Mapping Components
⌨️ (1:48:27) Mapping Components Practice
⌨️ (1:53:44) Todo App - Phase 3
⌨️ (1:58:16) Class-based Components
⌨️ (2:03:32) Class-based Components Practice
⌨️ (2:07:11) State
⌨️ (2:12:08) State Practice
⌨️ (2:15:45) State Practice 2
⌨️ (2:19:59) Todo App - Phase 4

⌨️ (2:25:52) Todo App - Phase 5

⌨️ (2:39:29) Todo App - Phase 6
⌨️ (2:47:14) Lifecycle Methods Part 1
⌨️ (2:56:45) Lifecycle Methods Part 2
⌨️ (3:00:07) Conditional Rendering
⌨️ (3:11:26) Conditional Rendering Part 2

⌨️ (3:23:00) Todo App - Phase 7

⌨️ (4:35:53) Meme Generator Capstone Project

⌨️ (5:03:06) Conclusion

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: freeCodeCamp.org
topLevelComment.text:
To get this code working, there is a little set up not mentioned in the video.
If you are coding on scrimba.com, click the gear icon in the top right corner and select 'add dependency...'. First add 'react', then add 'react-dom'. 
If you are building locally, you should first install create-react-app. Get it here: https://facebook.github.io/create-react-app/

topLevelComment.author: Raphael Castagna Haasper
topLevelComment.text:
Hello guys! Watching this october 2021! First of all, great tutorial! I wish every tutorial would be this good! 

Now, I got stump at ToDo App part 6. Even after copying his code as best as I could (we all know sometimes something ends up missing...) I could not get the state to change whenever I clicked on a task. After looking for an answer for hours I got it to work by replacing "onChange" to "onClick" and "checked" to "defaultChecked" inside the TodoItem component.  I don't know if this was a change made by React or if I got something wrong. Just thought I would come share my 2 cents in case someone else is stuck on that part.

topLevelComment.author: ChiefMiester
topLevelComment.text: Dude, as much as I love this guys way of teaching. I absolutely hate it when he uses arrow functions, it gets so confusing to understand which object is being returned to what function. Instead what would be better is if he manually made regular functions (instead of the arrow ones) and showed exactly what is being returned and how it's being utilised by the parent function/component. I'm sure experienced react native devs will prefer using arrow functions but for someone just learning everything from scratch it can get very confusing. I've spent way too long on Todo app phase 6 trying to understand how this guy is using arrow functions to change the state

replies.author: ChiefMiester
replies.text: @Bob Ziroll Wow didnt expect you to actually reply to my comment. Thank you for the insight, look forward to checking out the next course

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
I think it's less about the use of arrow functions and more that Todo app phase 6 is way too ambitious for a single challenge. In my upcoming re-make of this course, I made sure to take smaller "bites" for each challenge so it's not so overwhelming. I also use function declarations whenever I teach some new syntax so it's not confusing, but then switch them to arrow functions (since that's how you'll most oftentimes see anonymous functions these days).

So, keep an eye out for my upcoming Intro to React course :)

topLevelComment.text:
is it just me or the kind of tutorials you find youtube are too basic and they lack logic ? because of this I find it really hard to learn and master new technologies. I struggled to learn and master web development even, coz there was too much basic tutorials out there but none of them were based on real world applications. I took me some time, and combining information from different sources to be able to build real world applications and be job ready. 

Like when you work as a web developer you won't be building crud applications. You'll be building real applications with admin backend and frontend with business logic. I'm even thinking of starting my own youtube channel that will strictly be based on real world applications like e-commerce stores, Item ordering sites, classifieds sites, property listing sites etc

topLevelComment.author: Willy Gómez
topLevelComment.text: In 2:45:30, the “handleChangeFunction” is actually modifying the previous state, as opposed to creating a new object as is recommended earlier. This is because the “todo” object in the “map” function is being modified directly, instead of creating and using a copy of it. Using ES6 syntax, this could be fixed with “return {…todo, completed: !todo.completed}” in the body of the “if”

replies.author: Semih Öztürk
replies.text:
Hello bro. Just download visual studio code. And on command line, go into a file where you want to create your file. and type this
npx create-react-app "folder.name"  "folder.name" is your folder's name, if its react-apps, then you will type
npx create-react-app react-apps
and if you want to see it on browser, go in that file with this code,
cd react-apps
npm start
For all that to work you must install node.js first. So you need node.js, and visual studio code :) Good luck
Note: you may use another tool instead of visual studio code. But i think its one of the best.

replies.author: Neil Barnwell
replies.text: Okay I worked it out. It's caused by React.StrictMode. Basically you can't cheat and return the new array with the old (albeit modified) objects in. You have to return a whole new object graph. Basically we were cheating by returning the same objects, when we really need to perform deeper cloning operations (e.g. using Lodash or similar).

replies.author: George Georgopoulos
replies.text:
Make sure you don't use React.StrictMode in index.js which is the default code that is generated by npx create-rect-app.
 I had the same problem ... Installed Chrome react Dev tools  to debug in Chrome. It seems that for some reason, in this case the button change handler runs 2 times in a row so the boolean returns to the original value.  

I got it to work by deleting React,StrictMode from ReactDom render call in index.js like this

ReactDOM.render(
    <App />,
  document.getElementById('root')
);

this made the code work

topLevelComment.author: Ahmad Sheeraz Saeed
Firehawk VFX
topLevelComment.text:
COURSE BINGING IS AWESOME.  It's interesting, I just LOVE binging on courses.  But the key to doing it properly is having a big difficult problem to accomplish while doing it (something you care about), and having a reason for doing the course in the first place.  Otherwise it is pointless.  This allows me to take on an advanced course straight away, even if I don't retain everything, the most important thing is I will gain a map for what it looks like to implement the full features available to me.  I'll gain a framework and language to be able to google from to integrate that into the big problem I'm working on to solve.  If I started at beginner courses all the time and did things the slow way, it might actually take 10 times longer to realise that I shouldn't have even been using that tool in the first place for the problem I want to work on.  Give your self permission to watch a very difficult course on something you want to tackle, and see.  

Key ingredients to making this work for me are a big projector and beer.  

Giving yourself permission to not understand everything can hack your brain into loving really difficult things.

topLevelComment.author: Mauro Diaz
topLevelComment.text:
to complement the coment that @yuva kishore left, to setup ReactJS do as follows.

on your terminal, find the folder that will contain your project, then run:

1. npm init -y
2. npm install create-react-app -g
3. create-react-app 'your-app-name'
4. cd 'your-app-name'
5. npm start

Hope it is useful

replies.author: i-
replies.text: @Neeraj Shukla I agree. I still recommend going through the video completely because it gets a lot of the bigger points, but according to my friend, hooks make life super easy for some of these harder tasks. This video shows modifying state only through class-based components, and that seems to be the focus of the second half of the tutorial. Traditionally this is how it's supposed to be done, but now there are hooks in react which allow you to do it in functional components which are just easier to mess with in general. Also, his info on APIs is solid in this video but there now are implementations like Apollo that are designed for more modern applications. So overall, I recommend watching through the video still, but after, start learning about hooks and Apollo/GraphQL and hopefully that will make your life easier. Also, I have been using Next.js which is a framework based on the React.js library and it makes so many things so easy if you learn that too, but it's not necessary. Good luck!

topLevelComment.author: Raj Shah
topLevelComment.text: What you did at 2:45:10 is wrong because you are actually changing the object (toDo) which is inherently changing the prevState. topLevelComment.author: The Superior Man
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone whose CSS styles are not rendering, try importing your CSS file. You do this by using the keyword import followed by the path and the file name. So if your css file is named "MyStyles" and is located within  the same directory as the js file you are calling it from, then your code should begin with this:
import "./MyStyles.css"


This worked for me. The author did not do this, perhaps because older versions did not require css to be imported.

replies.author: Maria Z
replies.text: This worked for me:   import {styles} from './MyStyles.css'

topLevelComment.text:
After installing node, you can create your react app through these steps
1-  Go to your terminal and write " yarn global add create-react-app ", this will install  a few packages
2- After this type " create-react-app my-app", this will install the template and other things.
3- type " cd my-app " and you're good to go..
4- type "npm start" and the app will start running on your Local Host.

topLevelComment.author: Rabiya Rashid
topLevelComment.text: Awesome explanation(y). One thing I wanna ask is can we pass class variables to props? or is necessary to pass state variables. For instance I am receiving props from parent (level 1) and I want to do some manipulation on it (level 2) and then pass it to the grand child (level 3). So do I need to store the manipulated props (level 2) in state? For now I am storing the manipulated props in class variable e.g this.manipulatedValue = this.props.value + 2

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: Nope! You can pass whatever you want to pass through props. It doesn't matter where it's coming from - could be props passed down (CompA --> CompB --> CompC), could be state, could be a hardcoded value, it could even be a function, etc.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: It's because function declarations use their own `this` context, whereas the arrow function uses a "lexical this", meaning it doesn't create its own `this`. It's confusing, don't worry if it doesn't make a lot of sense. But in this case, you'll want to use an arrow function as the simple solution to your issue.

topLevelComment.author: Robert Zeurunkl
topLevelComment.text: If you omit semicolons, it's not like they aren't needed, and you don't have to have them.  Javascript will insert them for you, and it does sometime make mistakes abut where to put them that can lead to some really, REALLY hard to find bugs.  Best practice?  YOU decide where you want your statement to end instead of letting javascript guess.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: If you're following JavaScript standard conventions and good practices, JavaScript will never make a mistake on automatic semicolon insertion. It's only when you start formatting your code terribly or taking bad shortcuts that it can get confused.

replies.text: @RP No need for an extension, you just need to install Nodejs on your computer. After you do that, it should work.

replies.author: RP
replies.text: @Edwin L Hey Edwin - Im getting command response - bash: npx: command not found. I probably need to install a React extension, does it matter which one?

replies.author: Edwin L
replies.text: What I do is create a folder that is going to contain my project, lets say I call it my-app. Then open the terminal in Visual Studio Code. Its under View->Terminal. Once it's open, navigate to the same directory as your newly created folder. Then run the command "npx create-react-app my-app" . Afterwards type "cd my-app" to navigate to your folder. Lastly, type "npm start". Your react app should be set up!

replies.author: Brwa
replies.text:
go to npm and then install react components u only need to do step 1 once but other steps are needed each time you make another project , here is how you do it:
1)   npm install -g create-react-app
2)   create-react-app project-name   (note: project-name is just your project name use any name you want)
3)   cd project-name 
4)   npm start     ( this will open up the browser and your project is loaded in browser )
5) go to your program that you use to write html and js and css and open the project folder there you can find it in c/users/user-name/project-name
6)if you close everything and want to open the same project again just start from step 3 agnore but if you want to creat new one then start from step 2
hope it was helpful :)

replies.author: alb12345672
replies.text: @Dustin Cintron Another example, in vue, if you want to hide a div, simply add v-if="status" . There is also a v-show, if you are interested in the difference look it up! Vue will expand it behind the scenes to a component like in the tutorial. So all you are doing is adding an attribute to html. Not saying it is better or worse, but it requires you to learn a bunch of directives vs working with whole component packages to do something relatively simple. Angular is similar.

topLevelComment.author: Eleven
topLevelComment.text: What are other things that we need to learn in React to land a job?

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
Honestly, more often than not I've found that interviewers are mostly interested in learning about your ability to solve problems and communicate/work in a team. Many companies that use React don't use React in their interviews because they know if you're a good person, can learn quickly, communicate well, and can solve problems, they can teach you all the other stuff.


That being said, learning some more intermediate/advanced topics in React like handling performance issues, patterns like HOCs or render props, hooks, etc. are all going to be useful in your career with React.

topLevelComment.author: Brian Coverstone
topLevelComment.text:
Great tutorial!  I think when I realized that react transpiles lowercase JSX into html components that are not necessarily 1:1, and that HTML events were synthetic, React started making a lot more sense.

As a side note: I don't know how feasible that single modules can be small enough that they do not scroll, but I like the sentiment.  In our software, the largest module is over 20,000 lines of code (yes, that is ridiculous on the opposite side of the spectrum). But our average module size is about 2,000 lines. These days it is difficult to do anything without scrolling.

topLevelComment.author: Nicholas Saulsberry
topLevelComment.text: At Changing State, at about 2 hours and 30 min., it isn't properly explained why you can use prev.count as the parameter for setstate() . After looking at the React docs on reactjs I was able to see that the setstate() inherited from the REACT component has the option to receive an object to replace the current state like you explained but it can also take a function where the first parameter is automatically the current state which you didn't explain. I recommend clarifying that part. I noticed many books and tutorials skip over that part which I think could be confusing to beginners like myself. Great tutorial though.

topLevelComment.author: Joe LoMoglio
topLevelComment.text: If your looking for a video that will teach you how to setup and work with an actual local dev environment, this video is not for you. It uses Scrimba.com which is a sandbox and that's now how we build apps in the real world, so if your looking to learn so you can get a job and know how to setup and deploy, skip this video.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: True, it is a sandbox and people don't build production apps in a sandbox. BUT, I would argue when you're looking for a job in React, you're not likely going to be setting up the environment from scratch and will be working in an existing codebase. The curve introduced in setting up the React environment detracts from the fun of learning React for many people (from my years of experience teaching it), so teaching in a sandbox that abstracts the setup process away is a great way to learn that you love creating web apps with React enough to then learn the ancillary technologies like Webpack.

topLevelComment.author: paul fears
topLevelComment.text: good video, but react is slower than vanilla javascript.

replies.author: T
replies.text: @paul fears If all of this "overhead" is done on Node.js back-end using ReactDOMServer.renderToString()  and then the output is sent straight to any device it will be fast, client side.  Only time it needs to be parsed is when the server is reset.  It won't be long before everyone is carrying a wireless terminal to a super-computer cloud in their pockets.

replies.author: paul fears
replies.text: @T frameworks are slower. More overhead. More code for the javascript engine to parse. A google search will probably go into further depth. React IS faster when it comes to devolpment time. Which is important.

replies.author: T
replies.text: Slower how?  React prevents a device from unnecessary re-renderings of webpage components which increases responsiveness of a website, especially on slow-compared-to-desktop mobile devices.  It also uses a framework so it is much faster to read, understand, and update or modify for developers.

topLevelComment.author: JT Vlogs
topLevelComment.text: why use props when you can just use state?

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: They do different things entirely. If you want to pass data from a parent to a child, you MUST use props. If you want data that you can change from time to time, you use state. Neither is used to replace the other, and both are usually used in a React app with any kind of complexity.

topLevelComment.author: Mark Lancaster
topLevelComment.text:
Seems to me that React is overly complicating things.

Can you explain to me why state is used vs using a mutable object (like Angular does)?

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: @Mark Lancaster Sure thing! And if at all possible I'd highly recommend async/await. It's one of the best things that's come to JavaScript IMO :P But it doesn't work for every situation, so I'm sure you're on the right track with whatever you decide 👍🏻

replies.author: Mark Lancaster
replies.text:
@Bob Ziroll That's one comprehensive response. Thank you Bob! 

For one of our company's projects in particular I think we'd go far into the depths of callback hell if we made our post objects immutable (e.g. when making our own medium-style rich text editor), but I completely understand the asynchronous aspect of it. Thanks!

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
There's a few reasons. One is mutable objects can be unpredictable in certain circumstances. Immutability is becoming a widely-sought-after standard in many projects. (Immutable.js for example is often pulled in to React and Angular projects alike for this reason).

Another big reason is that React updates state (and the DOM) asynchronously. If you modify state twice in very quick succession, React will figure out how to handle that update in a smart way. If you choose to modify a state object directly, however, you may not get the result you expected because one update may complete before another.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
Jeremy Heminger It’s considered an anti pattern to use the index as the key. When you try to remove an item from the array, React won’t know which one needs to be removed.

Also, .map can take a second (and even 3rd) parameters: the index of the item in the array it’s currently looking at in that iteration of the loop, and the entire array itself. So if you ever need access to i, no need to declare and increment the variable yourself. 

TodosData.map((todo, i, array) => {...})

topLevelComment.author: James Harrison
topLevelComment.text:
For those who messaged me and others having problems setting up: He is using react in a demo environment that was setup without using create-react-app. The only advantage of using a stick built setup is that initially it will be about half the disk size(58MB) of a create-react-app build(110MB) because create-react-app includes more stuff that would have to installed with npm as needed with a stick build.  If you are starting out take a look here... https://reactjs.org/docs/create-a-new-react-app.html#create-react-app 

Any text editor will do for writing code (NOT A WORD PROCESSOR!)  Good free one here: https://code.visualstudio.com/
Install node  from here: https://nodejs.org/en/

From a shell / command prompt create a work area ... you can have as many as you want ...
npx create-react-app zot       ... this will create a directory under the current working directory with the name you provided(zot) with all the goodies you need to get started.
cd zot          ...goto the directory just created
npm start   ... this will fire up a localhost dev server on port 3000 (or next available port) in your default browser
Edit public/index.html directory and whack the comments and other unneeded stuff
Edit out the decoration crap in src/App.js
You are good to go!

topLevelComment.author: The Third Heat
topLevelComment.text: Question: How do you update the state changes to the parent when the change were made in the child?

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: The most common way is to define the function that updates the state (using setState) in the parent, then pass that function/method down to the child to execute. When the child executes that function, it will update the state in the parent. Any children the parent is passing that (now changed) state down to will re-render, and the new data will show up. 🎉

topLevelComment.author: mirzet dolic
topLevelComment.text: Can someone clarify why we did {props.product.name} and with the jokedata we did it {props.question}? also doing these differently in the component changed the way we did the mapping in App.js

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: With the productsData, we passed an entire object down via props. So `props.product` is an object with a `name` property, so to access the name you need `props.product.name`. With the jokes data we didn't pass an object, but just a simple string. So `props.question` IS the data you're trying to display. Hope that helps! 👍🏻

topLevelComment.author: Nguyen Tho
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for your video. I have a question. Should I use Reactjs for my portfolio website? If not, could you give me an advice?

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: It's impossible to say since it depends on exactly what you're hoping to accomplish with your portfolio site. Unless you have a lot of user interaction, React may be overkill, but if you're hoping to improve your skills in React in general, building ANYTHING with it is a win. There are also libraries out there that help you build static sites using React like Gatsby and react-static that you may want to look in to, but only after becoming pretty familiar with the core React library.

topLevelComment.author: theodark
topLevelComment.text: Adding ids to the array items, and using them as key, if you are creating dummy data from an API is the way to go.
